repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3663

This ensures that rvalues here are saved as temps, while keeping the
exisiting behaviour for `for x in deref(vec)`, where the pointer for vec
is copied, meaning it doesn't crash if vec is reassigned.

The bit of this change liable to have the biggest effect is that I've
changed the result type of dereference(x) and x[0] (where x is a c++
type) to a reference rather than value type. I think this is OK because
it matches what C++ does. If that isn't a sensible change then I can
probably inspect the loop sequence more closely to try to detect this.

comment_data.body: Is this really needed? Can't the decision be taken locally? Or via a helper method, e.g. `sequence_type.cpp_method_call("begin")` or even `sequence_type.struct_field_code("begin")` or something like that?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2661,7 +2661,8 @@ class IteratorNode(ExprNode):
     type = py_object_type
     iter_func_ptr = None
     counter_cname = None
-    cpp_iterator_cname = None
+    cpp_sequence_cname = None
+    cpp_attribute_op = "."

@@ -2859,14 +2877,12 @@ def generate_iter_next_result_code(self, result_name, code):
         if self.reversed:
             code.putln("if (%s < 0) break;" % self.counter_cname)
         if sequence_type.is_cpp_class:
-            if self.cpp_iterator_cname:
-                end_func = "%s->end" % self.cpp_iterator_cname
-            else:
-                end_func = "%s.end" % self.sequence.result()
-            # TODO: Cache end() call?
-            code.putln("if (!(%s != %s())) break;" % (
+            # end call isn't cached to support containers that allow adding while iterating
+            # (much as this is usually a bad idea)
+            code.putln("if (!(%s != %s%send())) break;" % (
                             self.result(),
-                            end_func))
+                            self.cpp_sequence_cname if self.cpp_sequence_cname else self.sequence.result(),

comment_data.body: Not sure. It isn't based on the `sequence_type`, it's based on either `sequence_type` or the temp type, so it'd still needs an attribute to store that. I'm sure it could be done differently, but when I try it typically ends up more convoluted.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2661,7 +2661,8 @@ class IteratorNode(ExprNode):
     type = py_object_type
     iter_func_ptr = None
     counter_cname = None
-    cpp_iterator_cname = None
+    cpp_sequence_cname = None
+    cpp_attribute_op = "."

comment_data.body: I think one thing that we can try now that `.analyse_types()` returns a node is to have a dedicated `CppIteratorNode` (sub-)class for C++ iteration, or even have more classes for the different iteration types, maybe with a common internal base class. I think C++ iteration is different enough to merit its own implementation. That would reduce both node classes to their respective use cases and would make these attributes appear less interfering.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2661,7 +2661,8 @@ class IteratorNode(ExprNode):
     type = py_object_type
     iter_func_ptr = None
     counter_cname = None
-    cpp_iterator_cname = None
+    cpp_sequence_cname = None
+    cpp_attribute_op = "."

comment_data.body: Does it need to inherit from `IteratorNode`? `AsyncIteratorNode` is a simple `ExprNode`, for example.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2910,8 +2840,107 @@ def free_temps(self, code):
         if self.iter_func_ptr:
             code.funcstate.release_temp(self.iter_func_ptr)
             self.iter_func_ptr = None
-        if self.cpp_iterator_cname:
-            code.funcstate.release_temp(self.cpp_iterator_cname)
+        ExprNode.free_temps(self, code)
+
+
+class CppIteratorNode(IteratorNode):

@@ -2910,8 +2840,107 @@ def free_temps(self, code):
         if self.iter_func_ptr:
             code.funcstate.release_temp(self.iter_func_ptr)
             self.iter_func_ptr = None
-        if self.cpp_iterator_cname:
-            code.funcstate.release_temp(self.cpp_iterator_cname)
+        ExprNode.free_temps(self, code)
+
+
+class CppIteratorNode(IteratorNode):

commit.message:
Handle `for x in cpp_function_call()`

Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3663

This ensures that rvalues here are saved as temps, while keeping the
exisiting behaviour for `for x in deref(vec)`, where the pointer for vec
is copied, meaning it doesn't crash if vec is reassigned.

The bit of this change liable to have the biggest effect is that I've
changed the result type of dereference(x) and x[0] (where x is a c++
type) to a reference rather than value type. I think this is OK because
it matches what C++ does. If that isn't a sensible change then I can
probably inspect the loop sequence more closely to try to detect this.

"X if X else Y" to "X or Y"

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>

commit.message: Move C++ iteration to its own CppIteratorNode

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Handle `for x in cpp_function_call()`
